titleStmt.title: Wert Thou but ill -- that I might show thee

publicationStmt.p: The Poems of Emily Dickinson, Johnson, 1955

lg.l: Wert Thou but ill -- that I might show thee
How long a Day I could endure
Though thine attention stop not on me
Nor the least signal, MineMine Me assure --
Wert Thou but Stranger in ungracious country --
And Mine -- the Door
Thou paused at, for a doubtfuldoubtful passing bounty --
No More --
Accused -- wert Thou -- and Myself -- Tribunal --
Convicted -- Sentenced -- Ermine -- not to Me
Half the distinctiondistinction Condition, thy Reverse -- to follow --
Just to partake -- the infamy --
The Tenant of the Narrow Cottage, we'rt Thou --
Permit to be
The Housewife in thy low attendance
Contenteth Me --
No Service hast Thou, I would not attempt --attempt -- achieve it --
To die -- or live --
The first -- Sweet, That wasThat was proved I, ere I saw thee --
For Life -- is --is -- means --means -- be Love --
